2.99.text:
Tomorrow marks the second annual Doctor Who
Comics Day.

6.34.text:
Comic book shops around the world are getting
involved

8.05.text:
there’ll be new ranges on sale, signings
and exclusive variant covers up for grabs

12.43.text:
We paid a visit to Titan’s headquarters
to speak to Range Editor Andrew James

16.69.text: to find out what’s on offer.

19.29.text: So first up, what is Doctor Who Comics Day?

22.81.text:
Doctor Who Comics Day is sort of an international
celebration of Doctor Who and comics

27.18.text:
It’s kind of an excuse to get comic book
stores all over the world to throw small parties

34.21.text:
Generally just have fun with the brand and
with the comics

37.93.text:
And that there are Doctor Who fans all over
the world and they really want to celebrate

43.13.text:
On Saturday 15th August people can go into
their local comic book store, pick up the

48.87.text:
Which is the first issue of our Doctor Who
event series of 2015

52.98.text:
Four Doctors, written by Paul Cornell with
art by Neil Edwards and colours by Ivan Nunes

57.89.text:
Comic book owners will be there to guide them
through the many titles that we’ve got

61.41.text:
And sort of say this is a great jumping on
point, try this out

64.03.text:
But yeah, there will be activities, quizzes
and all that sort of stuff

67.58.text:
It’s just a great excuse for a party and
it’s another way of celebrating and also

73.14.text:
That have been so supportive of us in our
first year of printing Doctor Who comics.

77.60.text:
So what can you tell us about Paul Cornell’s
Four Doctors?

81.53.text:
Well, it’s the first ever crossover between
Doctors Ten, Eleven and Twelve in any medium

86.91.text:
Ten is incredibly suspicious of Twelve because
he doesn’t believe he should actually exist

91.62.text:
From his perspective, this man should not
be here

95.43.text:
Eleven is sort of relieved to find that he
does actually carry on going

98.87.text:
He’s almost the peacemaker between Ten and
Twelve while their at each other’s throats

103.69.text:
Ten calls him famously, an ‘abomination’
to Twelve and Twelve is like ‘a Dalek word,

109.44.text:
And if you know anything about Doctor Who
since 2005 you’ll have an absolute blast

116.74.text: Oh! Sorry, this is really rather good.

120.52.text:
But with all these comics, where on Gallifrey
does one start?

123.80.text:
Luckily for us, TV presenter, Doctor Who fan
and comic book enthusiast, Chris Johnson,

128.51.text: is on hand to help us out.

130.71.text: Man, we got spoiled in 2013 didn’t we?

133.55.text:
Big Finish’s extravaganza The Light At The
End, a shiny new Peter Capaldi to look forward

138.80.text:
And some television special called The Day
of the Doctor or whatever, you might have

142.41.text:
But also we were treated to a 12 issue event
from IDW called Prisoners of Time.

147.42.text:
Featuring the first 11 incarnations of the
Doctor being perused throughout history alongside

152.51.text: By a mysterious figure hell bent on revenge

156.21.text:
Every issue you find out more about what this
person could be

161.18.text:
Highlights? The Eighth Doctor reunites with
Grace.

164.88.text:
The Eleventh faces of against the Anthony
Ainley incarnation of the Master.

168.90.text: The Fourth Doctor encounters the Judoon.

172.89.text:
And Frobisher is in it and I absolutely love
Frobisher.

177.21.text:
Doctor Who, the Ninth Doctor hot on the heels
of their three on-going Doctor Who titles

181.64.text: the mighty team at Titan bring us

183.70.text:
The Ninth Doctor limited series. This is a
sheer delight to read.

189.24.text:
Bringing back to life one of the most popular,
if short lived TARDIS trios in Doctor Who

196.13.text:
The Time War may have ended but the Ninth
Doctor has plenty of work to do yet

200.08.text:
Cavan Scott captures the characters voices
perfectly in this story that follows on directly

205.75.text: Of The Doctor Dances back in Series 1

208.15.text:
With artwork by Blair Shedd and Rachel Stott
bringing these characters to glorious life

212.51.text:
It’s amazing to finally see the Ninth Doctor
– my Doctor

215.91.text:
Rose Tyler and Captain Jack Harkness in a
brand new story that’s still going on to

220.60.text:
Whatever Doctor Who graphic novel takes your
fancy, whichever one grabs your eye, give

224.40.text:
They’re easy to leap into, they’re tonnes
of fun

227.03.text:
And what’s more, it’s more Doctor Who
in your life

229.07.text: And when is that a bad thing?

230.38.text:
Now if you don’t mind, I’m going to get
back to reading my comics

240.64.text:
Doctor Who comics wouldn’t be complete without
the incredible artwork.

243.68.text:
And some fans have made the leap from making
fan art to working on the comics themselves.

248.28.text:
Hi, my name is Rachel Stott, I’m a comic
book artist and I draw Doctor Who.

253.92.text:
So far I’ve done a little bit of Nine, a
little bit of Ten and then this year, well,

259.30.text: I’m going to be drawing the Twelfth Doctor

260.99.text:
I had been hired because the publishers had
seen some of my Twelfth Doctor fan art on

267.82.text:
And things like this and like being able to
draw something and knowing it’s like official

272.69.text:
And it was going to be on the front cover
of a Doctor Who comic book really, really

277.13.text:
I work digitally so basically I’ll receive
a script that looks like a movie script into

283.50.text:
And yeah, read it. Figure out how you want
the story to go because most of the time it

287.43.text:
like dialogue and a little bit about what
the character should be doing in each panel

292.16.text:
and then you just draw it out on the tablet
just like you would with paper or pen

296.11.text:
so you just sketch it out using blue for the
pencil line and sort of ink over the top of

301.37.text:
And then it gets sent off to another person
who colours it

305.01.text:
Someone else after that who puts the dialogue
like the word balloons onto the top of it

309.10.text:
And yeah, it gets printed out and it becomes
a beautiful comic book

312.65.text:
I was a Doctor Who fan before starting drawing
the books

315.05.text:
I’ve been watching it ever since Christopher
Eccleston’s first episode

317.64.text:
and ever since then I’ve literally been
hooked on it.

320.22.text:
It’s been my favorite TV show. I absolutely
adore it.

323.27.text:
So the fact that I get to draw it is slightly
surreal and really, really fantastic.

327.64.text:
My advice to budding comic book artists is
to draw as much as you can

334.62.text:
Draw from life especially because that’s
going to be really good practice for the future

339.26.text:
For budding Doctor Who artists, drawing drom
life doesn’t mean

342.45.text:
following Peter Capaldi and Jenna Coleman
around all the time because that’s not cool

347.43.text:
You know if you draw like your living room,
the same also applies to when you draw a spaceship

353.37.text:
It’s all just perspective and composition
and things like this

356.37.text: So yeah, just practice as much as you can.

359.26.text:
And have passion for it as well because if
you draw whatever you think you’re meant

363.64.text:
It might come out terrible because you’re
hearts not gonna be in it

367.11.text:
Draw whatever comes to you and whatever you
want to and then it will turn out fantastic

369.55.text:
And if it turns out terrible then you know
what to do next time to improve it

374.70.text: And get better and better and better

376.83.text:
Until I can ready your comic books then that
will be great.

380.68.text:
If you have anything you’d like to share
with us, email us at dwthefanshow@bbc.com

384.84.text:
or tweet us @dwthefanshow.
And finally, check out our favourite clips

387.98.text: in this week’s Who Tube Annotation Attack.
